turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about History of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth (1648–1764).
turn.1: What was the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth's final years like?
turn.2: The Treaty of Warsaw and the Silent Sejm settled numerous contentious issues and resulted in limited reform of the state, encompassing a part of what was demanded by the more enlightened szlachta political publicists (Stanisław Szczuka, Stanisław Dunin-Karwicki).
turn.3: Did the commonwealth become a united state?
turn.4: Poland-Saxony relationship was strictly limited to a personal union.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: Saxon ministers were barred from ruling on matters concerning the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
turn.7: Why did they settle on this?
turn.8: The King was to be able to keep only 1200 personal guard Saxon soldiers and was not allowed to reside in Saxony for prolonged periods.
turn.9: What happened after they negotiated the settlement?
turn.10: The Commonwealth military force was practically limited to 18,000 soldiers, but was secured by permanent taxing arrangements.
turn.11: Did the commonwealth ever become a united state?
turn.12: The state budget, while enlarged, was set at only a fraction of that of Russia or Prussia.
